  i 

PROGRAM AND LOANS SUMMARY 

Islamic Republic of Pakistan 
 
Two  loans  totaling  $320  million  equivalent  to  support  a  reform  program 
aimed at improving access to credit and other financial services: Improving 
Access to Financial Services (Phase I) Program (IAFSP). The loans will be 
accompanied by a technical assistance grant in the amount of $2 million.   
 
Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention TI-H (income-poverty) 
Sector: Finance 
Sub-sectors: Finance sector development  
Themes: Sustainable economic growth; capacity development 
Subthemes:  Promoting  economic  efficiency  and  enabling  markets; 
institutional development 
 
Category  C:    Environmental  assessment  of  policy  interventions  indicate 
that the program is unlikely to have adverse environmental impacts 
 
Involuntary resettlement: Category C 
Impact on indigenous people: Category C 
No  involuntary  resettlement  or  impact  on  indigenous  people  is  expected 
from implementation of the program. 
 
Pakistan has achieved economic growth rates averaging over 7.5% a year 
for  the  past  3  years.  Reforms  have  led  to  a  better  and  more  predictable 
environment for public and private investment and thus to job creation and 
higher  incomes.  This  growth  has  cut  poverty  and  increased  prosperity. 
However,  24%  of  the  population,  or  36  million  people,  still  live  below  the 
poverty  line.  Inclusiveness  and/or  the  sustainability  of  this  growth  require 
more reforms backed by specific actions targeting those left behind.  Many 
of  these  communities  live  in  rural  areas,  although  urban  poverty  is  not  a 
less  serious  matter.  Measures  focusing  on  inclusiveness  do  not  only 
support  equity,  they  are  also  good  business,  as  evidenced  by  the 
mainstreaming  of  microfinance  in  the  financial  sector.  Bringing  poor 
communities 
(either  as  self  employed 
entrepreneurs  or  through  micro-,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises) 
also  contributes  to  investment,  job  creation  and  welfare.  A  wide  range  of 
measures can be used to achieve this. Access to credit and other financial 
services can be made much easier, more transparent, cost effective, and 
efficient. This is the essence of the proposed program.   
 
Microfinance currently reaches fewer than 1 million people in Pakistan, but 
the  market  is  many  times  this  size  and  current  market  estimates  range 
over  20  million  people.  The  Government  has  made  microfinance  a  key 
theme  under  its  Medium-Term  Development  Framework  (MTDF)  2005–
2010  and  the  broader  Strategic  Directions  to  Achieve  Vision  2030. 
Building a more inclusive financial sector means deepening the quality of 
the  service  and  expanding  the  coverage,  while  at  the  same  time  striving 
for efficiency and sustainability. The sector has improved, but still does not 
touch vast numbers of people. The proposed reform program is meant to 
change this.  It will do so by developing an enabling legal and regulatory

environment  and  introducing  specific  actions  to  remove  bottlenecks  and 
constraints at two strategic levels (i) the formal and informal intermediary 
networks, and (ii) clients and potential clients. The action plans will focus 
on  key  success  factors.    These  include  the  promotion  of  technology  and 
applications  to  achieve  national  scale  at  reduced  cost  for  all  types  of 
financial  service  providers;  expanding  the  range  and  quality  of  financial 
products  and  services  including  those  for  the  Islamic  market;  developing 
public–private  partnerships  to  expand  outreach;  stepping  up  reliable 
business and credit information and systems; expanding fast, reliable and 
lower-cost remittance services for overseas workers; capacity building for 
institutions and authorities; and  support for literacy to improve access to 
finance and its utilization for sustained economic growth.  
 
Improving  access  to  financial  services  will  improve  opportunities  for  rural 
and  urban  communities  and  ultimately  reduce  poverty.  The  proposed 
IAFSP will increase access to better (and more tailored) financial services 
by the self-employed, as well as by micro and small sized companies. The 
program  targets  poor  and  low-income  households  but  also  individuals, 
including  women.  It  will  spearhead  outreach  and  product  and  service 
innovation,  and  utilize  new  technologies  and  applications  to  reduce  the 
transaction costs associated with the delivery of financial services. Public-
private partnerships and private sector participation will be promoted for a 
more robust and competitive market. 
 
The proposed loans are as follows: 
 
(i)  A  $300  million  loan  from  the  ordinary  capital  resources  (OCR)  of  the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) with an interest rate to be determined in 
accordance  with  ADB's  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based 
lending facility, a term of 15 years, including a grace period of 3 years, and 
other terms and conditions as set forth in the loan agreement. 
 
(ii)  A  loan  of  Special  Drawing  Rights  13,425,000  ($20  million  equivalent) 
from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources,  with  an  interest  rate  of  1.0%  per 
annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, a term of 
24  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years,  and  other  terms  and 
conditions as set forth in the loan agreement.  
 
The  expected  program  completion  date  is  24  months  from  effectiveness, 
and  the  program  loan  closing  is  expected  3  months  after  program 
completion. The loan will be released in two tranches. The first tranche of 
$120  million  will  be  made  available  when  the  Government  meets  the 
conditions  of  loan  effectiveness  and  complies  with  the  first  tranche 
conditions. The first tranche will comprise $100 million from OCR and $20 
million  equivalent  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources.  The  second 
tranche  of  $200  million  from  OCR  is  expected  to  be  released  within  24 
months  of  loan  effectiveness,  and  will  be  released  upon  satisfactory 
compliance with agreed-upon conditions.

endowment  fund  to  be  established  to  support  (i)  capacity  building  and 
training  of  financial  services  providers  to  promote    expansion  into  rural 
areas; product and service innovation, including savings, remittances and 
Islamic  financial  services;  adoption  and  integration  of  new  technologies 
and  applications  for  improving  access  to  financial  services;  (ii)  capacity 
building  and  training  of Government  and  regulatory  authorities  to  support 
development  of  an  inclusive  financial  sector  and  implementation  of 
measures  under  the  Program;  and  (iii)  literacy  programs  (financial  and 
basic) conducted by or on behalf of financial services providers for clients 
and  potential  clients  to  improve  access  to  financial  services  and  the 
utilization of finance.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) two proposed 
loans and (ii) a technical assistance grant to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Improving 
Access to Financial Services (Phase I) Program (IAFSP). 
 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

The overall fiscal deficit in FY2006 (excluding the impact of the earthquake) is estimated 
2. 
at  PRs261.6  billion  (3.4%  of  GDP).  If  earthquake-related  spending  is  included,  the  size  of  the 
deficit for FY2006 would be PRs327.3 billion (4.2% of GDP). Pakistan has achieved a high level 
of economic growth averaging over 7.5% for the past three years. With population growing at an 
average  rate  of  1.9%  per  annum,  the  real  per capita  income  has  grown  at  an  average  rate of 
5.6%  per  annum.  The  economic  growth  has  supported  a  significant  reduction  in  poverty; 
however, 24% of the population or 36 million people continue to live below the poverty line, and 
the  incidence  of  poverty  is  28%  in  rural  areas  compared  with  about  14%  in  urban  areas. 
Sustained growth is needed to reduce the poverty level still further. Further sustained economic 
growth requires a financial sector that is stronger and more effective in mobilizing savings and 
allocating these to productive use. Growth also must be more inclusive to ensure greater impact 
on  poverty,  and  the  financial  sector  correspondingly  must  be  inclusive  and  improve  access  to 
financial  services.  The  Government’s  commitment  to  sustained  expenditures  on  pro-poor 
sectors  is  reflected  in  the  Fiscal  Responsibility  and  Debt  Limitation  Act,  2005.  Under  this  law, 
social and poverty-related expenditures must be 4.5% of GDP or above in any given year and 
budgetary  allocations  to  health  and  education  must  double  from  the  existing  level  in  terms  of 
percentage of GDP during the next 10 years. Inclusive growth and inclusive financial sector are 
indeed  among  the  strategic  concerns  for  the  government.  The  Government’s  Medium-Term 
Development  Framework  2005–2010  and  “Strategic  Directions  to  Achieve  Vision  2030”  both 
highlight this. What does inclusive financial sector mean in Pakistan? It means broadening the 
outreach and deepening the service while striving for efficiencies and maintaining sustainability.  
 
3. 
In  recent  years,  Pakistan  has  been  moving  towards  the  direction  of  developing  an 
inclusive financial sector. Under the earlier microfinance program,1 emphasis was placed on the 
establishment of a statutory institution in 2000 as a strategic way to launch the sector. A small 
number of microfinance banks (MFBs) were subsequently established under separate law and 
regulations, however total outreach achieved to date is small and the majority of the poor have 
no  access  to  basic  savings/deposit  and  other  services.  This  proposed  program  marks  a 
significant step forward, and will assist the Government to implement timely reforms. It will build 
on  the  past  success  and  address  emerging  issues,  and  brings  in  new  technologies  and 
applications that can expand outreach, lower cost of financial services and improve efficiencies. 
Most  importantly,  the  program  will  support  Government  to  implement  policy  and  institutional 
change  in  the  financial  sector  with  strategic  and  systematic  frameworks  that  cut  across  the 
various subsectors.  
 

III. 

THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Sector Description and Performance2 

4. 
The majority of the population lives in rural areas where regular transaction services are 
limited. To expand access by the poor and low-income families to sustainable financial services, 

                                                 
1   Loan-1806-PAK: Microfinance Sector Development Program, approved 13 December 2000. 
2   Sources: State Bank of Pakistan, Pakistan Microfinance Network, Pakistan Post, and Poverty Alleviation Fund.  

 2 

 

     

development of the microfinance sector and the mainstreaming of microfinance services in the 
financial sector is essential. However, there are fundamental issues that need to be addressed 
through (i) effective land title and registration for poor and subsistence farmers; (ii) more mobility 
for women and the large rural population; (iii) development of products and services that met the 
local needs, including products those that comply with Sharia (Islamic Law); and (iv) a shift from  
overdependence  on  donor  funds  to  increased  commercialization  of  the  sector  for  sustainable 
services that can achieve scale for a successful national outreach. Access to credit is a form of 
financial  capital.  Microfinance  credit  and  other  financial  services  that  help  the  poor  to  receive 
remittances  and  build  savings  safely  can  also  help  them  gain  access  to  other  fundamental 
assets such as education, good health, shelter, and communications. Studies from a number of 
countries have shown that the rural poor’s lack of access to product and factor markets leaves 
them largely bypassed by the growth process. Making markets work for the poor is therefore a 
key  element  of  a  country’s  poverty  reduction  strategy.3  This  supports  the  view  that  the  poor 
should be actively engaged in the growth process, as opposed to being left simply to share in 
the benefits of growth (i.e. relying on the trickle-down effects of growth). Microfinance can help 
the  poor  gain  access  to  product  and  factor  markets,  and  increase  employment  and  income-
generating activities, thereby actively engaging them in the growth process. 
 
5. 
Of Pakistan’s 153 million people, more than 90 million live in rural areas where there are 
few opportunities for employment other than self-employment or subsistence farming. Access to 
credit  for  the  rural  poor  is  typically  limited  to  local  moneylenders  who  can  charge  excessively 
high rates of interest. Borrowing is often linked to life-cycle needs of poor households, such as 
the need to pay for marriage expenses or health care, rather than for investment or productive 
purposes.  In  the  1950s  and  1960s,  the  development  of  microfinance  in  Pakistan  focused  on 
agricultural  credit,  and  the  dominant  view  was  that  the  poor  primarily  needed  access  to 
subsidized credit. In the 1970s, there was a move to nationalize banks and most credit to small 
farmers was provided by government banks. Various schemes, including a small credit program 
for  women  were  provided  through  mobile  teams.  However,  the  fact  that  these  initiatives  were 
subsidized and measures were not taken to ensure their sustainability meant that they led to the 
rent-seeking outcomes and poor financial performance that have emerged in other developing 
economies.  
 
During the 1980s the Agha Khan Rural Support Programme (AKRSP) began operations 
6. 
in  the  northern  region  of  the  country  using  a  three-pronged  approach:  (i)  community 
development  through  community-based  organizations,  (ii)  infrastructure  development,  and 
(iii) resource mobilization through savings and credit. The success of this program led to other 
rural support programs (RSPs)4 and a holistic approach to rural development that dominated the 
microfinance  scene  in  Pakistan  in  the  1980s  and  1990s.  The  National  Rural  Support 
Programme  (NRSP)  was  established  in  1991  by  the  Government.  It  is  Pakistan’s  largest 
multisectoral rural development program and operates in 35 districts. NRSP is involved in social 
infrastructure  development  and  has  a  Microfinance  and  Enterprise 
mobilization  and 
Development  Programme.5  An  individual  lending  approach  targeting  entrepreneurs  in  urban 
slums  was  also  developed  during  this  time,6  and  the  Kashf  Foundation,  modeled  on  the 
Grameen Bank of Bangladesh, started operations in 1994. These were followed by other similar

7. 
Microfinance  is  an  integral  part  of  the  financial  sector  and  supports  the  growth  of  local 
markets.  It  can  encompass  a  range  of  services,  including  deposits,  loans,  payment  services, 
money transfers, remittances, leasing, and insurance. To date, however, the focus has been on 
the provision of microcredit. Microfinance clients typically lack assets for collateral and are self-
employed in the informal sector or engaged in economic livelihood activities. Loans are based 
on the borrower's household's net cash flow and on non-traditional forms of security, and may 
be provided either on a group or an individual lending basis.7  Microfinance services in Pakistan 
are provided by microfinance banks (MFBs); commercial banks; rural support programs (RSPs); 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs); leasing companies and the national postal system.  
 
8. 
The  Government  established  the  first  microfinance  bank  in  Pakistan,  Khushhali  Bank 
(KB), under the KB Ordinance, 2000. While initial operations focused on a joint venture with the 
NRSP,  this  strategy  was  not  successful  and  the  concept  of  growth  through  “hubs”  was 
developed.  To  date,  KB  has  227,684  active  borrowers,  63  branches,  and  124  service  centers 
nationwide.  This  has  been  an  important  development  for  the  sector,  but  KB  has  focused  its 
efforts only on the provision of microcredit. Two basic loan products are offered: (i) a bullet loan, 
which is primarily for supporting agricultural activities; and (ii) a monthly installment based loan 
for trading activities. KB does not offer deposit services to its clients, although savings services 
are an important service for the poor. The bank currently uses only $30 million of its credit line 
for  its  loan  portfolio  and  $40 million  is  invested  in  its  treasury  operations.    KB  has  not  yet 
achieved  financial  sustainability  (after  exclusion  of  direct  and  indirect  subsidies),  continues  to 
rely on donor credit line, and has a low retention rate of clients (about 27% compared with about 
70% for many NGOs).     
 
9. 
The  Microfinance  Institutions  Ordinance,  2001  was  enacted  to  promote  access  to 
sustainable microfinance for the poor and ultimately to lead to poverty reduction. This ordinance 
(as  amended  by  the  Finance  Bill,  2006)  specifies  that  a  microfinance  client  must  be  below  a 
threshold  income  level  set  by  the  State  Bank  of  Pakistan.  Prudential  regulations  for 
microfinance  banks  and  institutions  set  the  maximum  microfinance  loan  size  at  PRs100,000. 
The  effect  of  the  Microfinance  Institutions  Ordinance  has  been  to  expand  the  outreach  of 
microfinance through the creation of licensed microfinance banks (MFBs) providing services to 
approximately 300,000 poor and very poor clients. However, the microfinance sector in Pakistan 
is relatively small compared with similar sectors in other countries in the region and is estimated 
to reach only 10% of the 6 million poor households in the country. Most of the poorest people 
have  no  access  to  formal  or  semi-formal  financial  services,  since  providing  microfinance 
services to the poorest involves high operating costs, intensive social intermediation, and high 
risk.  However,  empirical  evidence  suggests  that  there  is  a  large  potential  large  demand  for 
microfinance services among the poorest, especially for savings and remittances facilities.   
 
Besides  KB,  5  other  banks  are  licensed  in  Pakistan,8  including  four  nationwide  banks 
10. 
and  two  district-wide  banks.  It  is  estimated  that  40  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs)  operate  in 
the country, and that 19 of these capture almost 99% of the market. As of May 2006, there were 
584,836 active borrowers with a gross loan portfolio of PRs6.03 billion,9 compared with 510,000

11.  Microfinance  banks  and  commercial  banks  conducting  microfinance  business  are 
regulated and supervised by the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP).  Other types of institutions are 
generally self-regulating members of the Pakistan Microfinance Network (PMN), and follow the 
PMN framework of disclosure of financial and operational performance. PMN was established in 
1997 and is dedicated to improving the reach and sustainability of microfinance in Pakistan. It 
publishes  an  annual  performance  indicators  report.  Its  mission  is  to  support  provision  of 
financial services to the poor, with a focus on retail microfinance. The objectives of PMN are to: 
(i) promote  an  enabling  environment  that  benefits  the  work  of  all  stakeholders;  (ii)  build  the

12.  MFIs can register themselves at the district level (where the capitalization requirement is 
PRs100 million), at the regional level (where the requirement is PRs150 million, recently added 
through amendments to the Microfinance Institutions Ordinance), at the provincial level (where 
the  requirement  is  PRs250  million),  or  at  the  national  level  (where  the  requirement  is  PRs500 
million).  However,  given  the  scale  of  operations,  these  capital  requirements  may  be  too  high, 
and  recent  prudential  regulations  from  the  SBP  have,  to  a  certain  extent,  reduced  them  by 
accepting the outstanding portfolio (if of a good quality) of the MFI, at the time of transformation, 
as part of the initial capital.

13. 
Financial services are also provided through Pakistan Post, a state enterprise providing 
a range of postal products and public services, including financial services, through a network of 
12,267  post  offices  across  the  country.  Financial  services  include  remittance  services  through 
money orders. A money order is an order issued by the post office for the payment of a sum of 
money  through  the  agency  of  the  post  office.  Almost  all  post  offices  are  money  order  offices, 
and the maximum size of a money order is PRs10,000. Postal order services are also provided, 
to fulfill requirements for small remittances. For faster transmission, a fax money order service is 
offered at district and other post offices. To cater to the needs of the urban population and the 
business community, the postal draft service is a remittance service operating among head post 
offices. It is used for remittances by individuals or organizations and the maximum postal draft 
value is PRs200,000. In addition to remittance services, Pakistan Post also has a saving bank. 
Serving  as  an  agent  of  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  the  saving  bank  has  played  a  crucial  role  in 
encouraging  and  mobilizing  savings  among  the  general  public.  In  most  remote  areas,  it  is  the 
only banking services available. Pakistan Post does not provide loans.  

14.

199711  as  an  autonomous  body  working  with  local  partners  to  provide  loans,  grants  and 
technical  assistance  to  the  poorest  individuals  and  communities  in  the  country.  Sponsored  by 
the Government of Pakistan and funded by the World Bank and others, the PPAF currently has

committed to enhancing the economic welfare and income of disadvantaged peoples. Benefits 
accrue  directly  to  the  vulnerable  through  income  generation,  improved  physical  and  social

1. 

Lack of National Strategy for Inclusive Financial Sector 

17. 
State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has emphasized that building sustainable financial services 
systems for the poor is of critical interest and requires laying a foundation for potentially profitable 
market and enterprises that can develop ways to reduce the costs and risks of serving them. Both 
SBP  and  the  banking  industry  are  working  towards  exploring  options  on  how  to  reach  financial 
services  to  un-banked  segments  of  the  population.12  While  encouraging  e-banking  and  e-
commerce, SBP is now working closely with the banking industry to explore options for adoption 
of new technologies to reach under-banked areas with the objective of enhancing access of rural, 
agriculture  and  microfinance  credit  and  to  attract  remittances.  In  this  respect,  strategic  alliances 
with overseas partners with special compatibility are encouraged by SBP. SBP’s reorganization in 
September  2006  also  reflects  the  dynamic  markets  and  developments  taking  place  across 
Pakistan’s financial markets. A Development Finance Group was established within SBP to create 
an  enabling  environment  to  facilitate  intermediation  and  help  develop  capacities  to  better 
understand  the  new  niche  areas  such  as  infrastructure,  Islamic  banking,  housing,  SME  and 
microfinance. A creation of a Task Force for a National Strategy for an Inclusive Financial Sector 
comprised  of  representatives  from  SBP,  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF),  Ministry  of  Information 
Technology (MOIT), Pakistan Post, Pakistan Microfinance Network and other concerned agencies 
will facilitate the development of a comprehensive and crosscutting national strategy that can build

2. 

Overdependence on Donor Funds  

 
18. 
Historically, the development of microfinance and SME finance has been supply-driven 
and focused on the provision of subsidized credit lines to promote growth. A common view was 
that the poor were “beneficiaries” of finance schemes, without the capacity to save. Those who 
did save were regarded as preferring non-financial forms of saving, and it was felt that the poor 
could not afford the full cost of credit at commercial rates. This view was a common view taken 
internationally in early stages of development of the sector when less information was available 
and little was understood about the full capacity of this segment of the market. This earlier view 
led to an institutional response in Pakistan and other countries that was supply-led and focused 
on  subsidized  credit  programs  by  governments  and  international  donor  agencies.  Private 
financial  institutions  developed  a  high  dependency  on  external  borrowings  and  mobilization  of 
savings was neglected. In the long run, sustainable finance requires a shift from a supply focus 
to  a  demand-driven  market  system.  Subsidized  credit  lines  and  programs  can  “crowd  out” 
private  sector  development  and  undermine  the  development  of  savings  services  which  can 
provide a lower cost, sustainable source of operational funds required to achieve national scale. 
Overdependence  on  donor  funds  can  also  result  in  complacency  and  lack  of  efforts  to  offer 
savings/deposit  services  to  clients,  as  has  been  the  case  with  KB,13  which  provides  no 
savings/deposit services to clients. The commercialization of microfinance for the development 
of sustainable financial services that can achieve the scale necessary for national outreach is a 
topic  that  has  been  researched  and  documented  in  many  international  studies.14  The 
recognition of profit opportunities for this market segment is also seen with the continued entry 
of  new  institutions,  both  at  the  country  level  and  internationally.  Funds  such  as  the  Global 
Commercial  Microfinance  Consortium15  are  indicative  of  the  type  of  facilities  being  created  to 
capitalize on the growing opportunities for microfinance.     
 

3. 

Technical Challenges and High Transaction Costs  

At present, there are limited commercial or microfinance bank operations in rural areas 
19. 
providing  a  full  range  of  financial  services  for  the  poor.  Although  Pakistan  Post  offers  a  great 
opportunity for expansion through a network of more than 12,000 post offices, this capacity has 
not  yet  been  tapped  for  the  widespread  delivery  of  diverse  financial  services.    Despite  the 
expansion  of  institutional  and  policy-directed  credit,  informal  markets  still  supply  most  of  the 
credit  needed  by  the  poor  because  the  banking  sector  primarily  services  urban  and  industrial 
needs. Credit in rural areas is mostly supplied by commission agents and other middlemen at 
high  interest  rates.  Shortages  of  capital  at  affordable  rates  constrain  the  growth  of  the  rural 
economy,  and  prevent  efficient  resource  mobilization  and  risk  management.  Insufficient 
infrastructure  and  outreach  in  rural  areas  has  resulted  in  some  cases  in  debt  bondage  for 
workers.16  This  is  a  system  of  advance  payment  and  “voluntary”  economic  transactions, 
whereby  a  worker  transacts  with  the  employer  for  credit,  repaying  the  debt  by  working  for  the 
creditor. Given the high rates and low wages that often prevail, it is difficult for workers to repay

20. 
Although  there  is  debate  as  to  the  true  level  of  access  to  credit  for  women,  it  is  low 
relative  to  experiences  in  the  region  and  internationally.  Women  have  taken  out  only  16%  of 
total  outstanding  loans.  The  main  reasons  for  this  are  constraints  on  the  mobility  of  women, 
especially in rural areas, and other cultural constraints. As women may not be allowed to travel 
unaccompanied  or  outside  village  areas,  their  access  to  resources  is  considerably  curtailed. 
Many  women  do  not  possess  identity  cards,  although  they  are  available  to  all  residents.  The 
principal barriers to gender equality include a perception of women as lower status dependents; 
lack of information about opportunities, assets and services; absence of control over resources; 
restricted  mobility;  non-marketable  skills;  violence  and  fear  of  violence;  and  a  shortage  of 
available  services  and  opportunities.17  Some  institutions  are  exploring  how  to  reach  women, 
such as Tameer Microfinance Bank, which is recruiting a female sales force to improve outreach 
in communities.18  
 
21. 
Adoption  of  new  technology  and  applications  can  provide  the  strategic  means  of 
reaching women and people living in rural and remote areas. Measures that can be undertaken 
in the near term to increase both physical access to financial services and participation in rural 
communities among the poor and illiterate include the use of mobile money transfers using cell-
phone-based  technology  to  provide  low-cost  alternatives  and  access  to  the  poor  where  there 
are  no  bank  branches.  Such  applications  are  being  implemented  in  the  Philippines  and  some 
countries in Africa where cell phone penetration is high, even among poor households. The cell 
phone  penetration  in  Pakistan  is  currently  about  30%  and  is  growing  rapidly,  indicating  a 
potential market for such technological solutions. For improving access outside cellular service 
areas,  technology  is  evolving  toward  access  via  satellite  to  cell  phones,  and  pilot  projects  are 
underway  in  the  region.  The  poor  are  often  “connected,”  own  cellular  phones,  and  may 
purchase  a  cellular  phone  before  many  other  basic  items.  Being  poor  does  not  mean  being 
without technology. Technology can improve access to financial services as well as to market 
and  other  information  that  can  positively  impact  the  livelihood  of  the  user.  The  National 
Database  Registration  Authority  (NADRA)  is  currently  providing  new  computerized  national 
identity cards that are biometrically enabled (finger and face). As of March 2006, about 47% of the 
adult  population  had  received  identity  cards,  and  full  adult  coverage  is  expected  soon.  The 
mission  of  the  NADRA  program19  is  to  build  a  biometrically-enabled,  centralized  public  data 
warehouse to support all facets of public life, including public records, banking, travel, education, 
and health care. This system will support access to finance for all and will facilitate access through 
technologies such as cell-phone-based money transfers and remittances. To facilitate adoption of 
technologies and applications in the financial services sector, measures from the Central Board 
of  Revenue  (CBR)  will  be  important  in  order  for  financial  services  providers  to  avail  of  the 
reduced rate of import taxes and sales tax exemption on technology hardware that are provided 
to  other  service  sectors.  The  rationalization  of  registration  and  annual  license  fees  by  the 
Pakistan  Telecommunications  Authority  (PTA)  will  also  be  important  to  support  increased 
outreach of financial services through adoption of technologies and applications.

4. 

Lack of Reliable Business and Credit Information and History 

a. 

Outmoded Land Registration System 

Lack  of  access  to  credit  because  of  the  poor  quality  of  land  records  prohibits  people, 
22. 
especially  inhabitants  of  rural  areas,  from  participating  in  economic  activities.  Land  titles  are 
maintained manually and are often not relied on by financial institutions when they are considering 
loan applications because of concerns about the accuracy, completeness, and authenticity of data. 
Banks and other financial institutions have their own processes for verifying the title and value of 
land,  which  makes  borrowing  against  land  titles  cumbersome,  difficult  and  costly.  Land  records 
form  the  basis  for  assignment  and  settlement  of  land  titles  and  are  crucial  for  proving  land 
ownership,  land  taxes,  reforms,  and  administration.  Computerized  land  records  will  help  in  the 
effective collection and analysis of data, which can be used to verify collateral for loans.  
 
23. 
In  2003,  a  pilot  scheme  for  the  computerization  of  Revenue  Management  Information 
System  (REMIS)  began  in  five  districts  of  Sindh  Province.  In  July  2006,  the  Government  of 
Sindh  approved  a  project  called  the  Computerization  Program  of  Revenue  Collection, 
Assessment  and  Accounting  System,  with  Special  Emphasis  on  Ownership  of  Title  through 
REMIS.  The  total  cost  of  the  project  is  PRs432  million,  wholly  funded  by  the  Government  of 
Sindh.  The  goals  of  the  project  are  to  (i)  maintain  records  of  rights  over  land;  (ii) execute  an 
efficient mutation process related to land ownership; (iii) improve land records service delivery 
and  transparency;  and  (iv)  computerize  and  generate  all  revenue  forms  electronically.  The 
project  will  cover  all  23  districts  in  the  province.  The  Government  of  Sindh  asked  ADB  for 
advisory technical assistance for capacity building, and for funding for a geographic information 
system  (GIS)  and  software  for  land  surveys  and  GIS  records.  The  establishment  of  an 
automated land registration and records management system in Sindh will improve the quality 
of  land  records  and  processes,  and  increase  access  to  bank  credit  for  small  and  subsistence 
farmers. This initiative complements the land registration project launched in Punjab province in 
June 2006 with support of the World Bank and the Department for International Development of 
the UK (DFID).20  These two provinces account for 79% of the population and 44% of the land 
area in Pakistan (Balochistan accounts for 44% of the country’s land area, yet only about 5% of 
the  population).  Development  of  automated  land  registration  in  these  provinces  will  have 
significant impact for improving the quality and security of land records. 
  

b. 

Limited Credit Information Bureau Coverage  

 

Lack of reliable business information and credit history has been a major impediment to 
24. 
the  growth  of  financing  for  the  poor  and  for  microenterprises.  The  establishment  of  a  credit 
information  bureau  (CIB)  for  banks  has  been  an  important  development,  but  the  reporting 
requirement has previously been too high to capture potential microfinance customers. SBP has 
now  removed  the  reporting  limit  of  PRs500,000  which  means  that  information  of  value  to 
microfinance will be captured. SBP and the Pakistan Microfinance Network recognize the need 
for a credit information bureau for all types of institutions (regulated and unregulated), including 
microfinance  banks,  rural  support  programs  (RSPs),  and  other  NGOs.21  Broader  credit 
information  coverage  is  especially  important  in  rural  areas  where  RSPs  and  NGOs  are  key 
providers of financial services.  Expanded credit reporting can provide both negative information 
about defaults by potential new customers, and positive information on credit histories that can 
reduce potential adverse selection and moral hazards which increase costs of lending. Broader 
CIB  coverage  can  also  prevent  the  over-indebtedness  that  can  occur  when  borrowers  take

multiple loans when credit histories remain private between the institutions and their borrowers. 
This  will  be  increasingly  important  as  commercial  lenders  expand  their  targeting  of  the 
microfinance market. An expanded credit reporting system can also promote competition among 
lenders,  and  provide  good  customers  with  alternative  sources  of  finance.  PMN  has  been 
examining credit information systems in countries such as Bolivia that address credit information 
for both formal and informal lenders. One issue for establishment of a private CIB is the funding 
for ongoing operations – will the demand for reports and the willingness to pay be sufficient to 
sustain operations. According to PMN, that potential was not clear 3 years ago. Today, based 
upon  a  PMN  competition  survey  conducted  in  Lahore  in  2006,  PMN  officials  state  that  the 
demand  is  high  for  such  credit  information  service  in  the  expanding  and  competitive  Lahore 
market.  A  feasibility  study  to  determine  the  potential  design,  operations,  and  initial  capital 
required is needed to pilot an expanded CIB covering regulated and unregulated institutions.     
 

Lack of Diverse Financial Services and Products  

 
5. 

25. 
To date, most MFIs in Pakistan have focused only on credit delivery and other financial 
service providers are only now beginning to examine how diverse products and services can be 
offered  to  poorer  communities.  The  National  Human  Development  Report22  showed  that  the 
poor  have  very  high  ratios  of  loan  dependence  on  landlords,  and  that  such  a  high  rate  of 
indebtedness is a major hurdle for poverty reduction programs that are based on credit alone. 
The  lack  of  functioning  financial  markets  has  affected  the  poor  disproportionately.  With  few 
assets  that  can  serve  as  collateral,  they  have  traditionally  been  shut  out  of  formal  finance 
markets.  As  a  result,  the  poor  have  had  limited  possibilities  for  consumption  smoothening  in 
response  to  income  and  other  risks,  or  for  financing  production  enterprises  and  longer-term 
investments  through  saving,  lending,  or  insurance.  Poverty  is  thus  perpetuated,  as  the  poor 
cannot  exploit  economic  opportunities.  Savings  services, 
transfers, 
remittance  services,  and  products  and  services  that  comply  with  Sharia  (Islamic  Law)  are 
among the range of services needed for low income families and the poor.   
 

insurance,  money 

a. 

Savings and Remittances 

26. 
Savings are needed by all households for smoothening income and consumption flows, 
but  they  are  especially  vital  for  the  poor.  Savings  can  mitigate  risks  and  finance  productive 
investments in informal enterprises and farms. The poor save in a variety of financial and non-
financial ways and their primary need is to swap small savings flows for lump sums. Although 
the capacity to save is present including in Pakistan's rural areas, it is not being tapped because 
of a lack of institutional outreach. As a result, people in rural areas often save through livestock 
that can be bought and sold when needed. Hoarding gold and silver is also common in rural and 
semi-urban areas. Traditionally, jewelry is meant to be kept for a lifetime and transferred to the 
children, only to be utilized as a last resort through sale or mortgage. Mobilization of savings is 
essential if sustainable microfinance is to be developed nationally. As MFI deposits increase, so 
does the pool of available resources for MFIs to provide other services and expand their reach. 
The rate of savings mobilization will have a critical impact on the targeted growth and outreach 
of the microfinance sector. One potential source for rapid mobilization of savings is remittances 
from overseas workers. Funds from inward remittances are the second largest source of foreign 
exchange  inflows  after  exports.  Although  many  remittances  are  through  formal  channels,  an 
equal or greater number take place through informal channels.  Many poor do not have access 
to formal money transfer and remittance services. Instead they rely on informal channels, such 
as the physical transport of cash across borders. Formal money transfers can be costly, but cell-
phone-based technology can facilitate money transfers at a greatly reduced cost to the sender.

Saudi  Arabia,  United  Arab  of  Emirates,  GCC  countries  (including  Bahrain,  Kuwait,  Qatar,  and 
Oman), United Kingdom and European Union countries amounted to $1,242.49 million, $750.44 
million,  $716.30  million,  $596.46  million,  $438.65  million  and  $119.62  million  respectively. 
Remittances received from Australia, Canada, Japan, Norway, Switzerland, and  other countries 
during the last fiscal year amounted to $724.07 million. 
 
Facilitation of cheap, safe and speedy transmission of funds from overseas Pakistanis to 
27.  
their families is an active agenda of the Government and SBP. To facilitate home remittances 
and  to  expand  formal  services  to  households  and  promote  a  robust  and  competitive  market, 
SBP  has  issued  instruction  to  commercial  banks  to  establish  “Home  Remittance  Cells”  with 
dedicated professional personnel and IT experts. The amount of overseas workers remittances 
for  fiscal  year  ended  June  2006  transmitted  through  formal  channels  totaled  $4.6  billion.  An 
equal  or  greater  amount  of  remittances  is  considered  to  flow  through  informal  channels, 
representing  both  a  loss  of  revenue  for  financial  services  providers  and  a  welfare  loss  for 
remitters  who  are  forced  to  send  money  home  via  risky,  costly  and  otherwise  inefficient 
remittance  channels.  The  formalization  of  this  market  would  be  both  pro-poor  and  welfare 
enhancing for the economy as a whole.24 Authorizing microfinance banks to receive remittances 
directly from overseas Pakistanis will be important for expanding remittance services, especially 
for those microfinance banks expanding into rural areas where many remittances are sent.

Islamic Financial Products and Services 

28. 
The  Second  World  Islamic  Economic  Forum  was  held  in  Pakistan  in  November  2006, 
marking  the  increasing  importance  of  Islamic  financial  services  in  emerging  markets  worldwide. 
Memoranda  of  understanding  were  signed  at  the  forum,  including  one  between  SBP  and  the 
International  Centre  for  Education  in  Islamic  Finance25  (INCEIF)  for  the  development  of  Islamic 
finance in Pakistan.  There is a recognized and growing demand for Islamic financial products and 
services in Pakistan.  In rural areas, it is believed that, even if financial services are available, they 
may  not  be  used  because  they  do  not  comply  with  Sharia  (Islamic  Law).  To  meet  this  demand 
and to provide a more diversified product and service sector, Islamic financial services need to be 
further developed and offered through multiple channels with product designs that can reach the 
microlevel.  SBP  has  shown  a  strong  commitment  to  promoting  development  of  Islamic  financial 
services in Pakistan. SBP established an Islamic banking department, and task forces have been 
set  up  to  promote  Islamic  research  and  development  and  Islamic  liquidity  management

instruments.26  SBP  is  also  member  of  the  Islamic  Financial  Services  Board  (IFSB),  an

could facilitate establishment. 
 

6. 

Unequal Treatment of MFBs 

29. 
A key issue for more rapid development of financial services in remote and rural areas is 
the  need  for  equal  treatment  for  all  microfinance  banks.  The  role  of  private  microfinance  is 
critical, but  emphasis on a single institution, the KB has had limited results. Initially viewed as a 
strategic approach to launching the sector, dedicating resources to a single bank has resulted in 
a skewed and inefficient market. This included the dedication of endowment funds available for 
its use which were not available to other practitioners. To remove this unfair advantage and to 
ensure  transparency,  such  funds  should  be  factored  into  the  overall  costs  of  banking  for  KB. 
The  existence  of  two  ordinances,  one  for  the  KB  and  one  for  all  other  microfinance  banks, 
heightens the perception that KB is separate from other market players, and the image of KB as 
a Government institution. The shares of KB are owned by 16 private banks, one of which, the 
National Bank of Pakistan (NBP), is majority owned by the Government. NBP’s shareholding in 
KB is currently 23.5%. The main advantage enjoyed by KB is the large credit and special funds 
targeted for it, and SBP is trying to resolve issues arising from existing restrictions under these 
funds.  Introduction  of  a  draft  bill  to  bring  all  MFBs  under  the  same  legal  and  regulatory 
framework would be an important measure for equal treatment of MFBs.  
 

7. 

Literacy (Basic and Financial) 

30. 
Literacy  is  important  if  the  disadvantaged  poor  are  to  be  introduced  to  a  formal  or 
semiformal  market-oriented  institutional  environment  and  effectively  access  financial  services. 
Many of the poor are not well informed about microfinance services or how to access them. In 
addition,  many  people  are  not  literate  and  cannot  even  sign  their  names.  Loan  officers  can 
explain  to  them  the  loan  agreement  and  obligations,  but  many  people  can  not  read  what  is 
being signed, which increases the vulnerability of the poor. Some microfinance institutions, such 
as Rozgar Microfinance Bank and the Network Microfinance Bank, support their client with basic 
literacy  training.  Literacy  and  education  are  important  for  determining  the  likelihood  of 
household  participation  and  access  to  financial  services.  Survey  data28  on  the  microfinance 
sector  in  Pakistan  show  that  household  heads  participating  in  microfinance  had  significantly 
higher literacy rates than household heads in non-participating households (67% literate males 
in participating households as compared with 47% in non-participating households).  Similarly, 
35% of respondents from participating households had completed their matriculation or attained 
a higher level of education, while only 14% of respondents among non-participating households 
had  achieved  this  level.  The  disparity  is  clear  and  the  potential  impact  large.  The  survey  also 
showed  that  a  considerable  proportion  of  households  experienced  a  sustainable  increase  in 
their income after receipt of a loan.

8. 

Capacity Building of Financial Services Providers and Authorities  

31. 
Strengthening the institutional capacity of financial services providers is important if they 
are  to  grow  and  reach  the  poor.  There  needs  to  be  a  wider  and  clearer  application  of  the 
principles  of  sustainable  microfinance,  and  interest  rates  need  to  cover  the  true  cost  of 
operations.  Even  the  best  institutions  need  to  improve  their  credit  management,  their 
delinquency management practices, and their accounting for bad debts and provisioning in their 
income  statements.  Portfolio  quality  is  a  concern,  with  portfolio-at-risk  (PAR)  reported  to  be 
18.5%.  The  private  sector  has  to  apply  its  resources  more  strategically,  improve  on  efficiency 
standards,  and  use  better  management  information  systems,  which  can  help  it  to  enhance 
outreach and quality. Many MFIs lack basic skills for sustainable, effective, and efficient delivery 
of  microfinance  services  to  the  poor.  Inefficiencies  can  result  in  higher  operating  costs  that 
translate into unnecessarily high interest rates for the poor. MFIs face high transaction costs in 
the  operation  of  their  business;  however  improved  efficiencies  and  skills  development  could 
help to lower these costs.  
 
Adoption of technologies and applications will also require capacity building and training 
32. 
across all types of financial services providers (commercial banks, Islamic banks, MFBs, NGOs, 
RSPs,  and  others).  Literacy  and  education  are  important  for  determining  the  likelihood  of 
household  participation  and  access  to  financial  services.  Survey  data29  on  the  microfinance 
sector in Pakistan show that household heads of households participating in microfinance had 
significantly  higher  literacy  rates  among  than  did  those  in  non-participating  households  (67% 
literate  males  in  participating  households  as  compared  with  47%  in  non-participating 
households).  Similarly, 35% of respondents from participating households had completed their 
matriculation or attained a higher level of education, while only 14% of respondents among non-
participating households had achieved this level. The disparity is clear and the potential impact 
large.  The  survey  showed  that  a  considerable  proportion  of  households  experienced  a 
sustainable increase in their income after receipt of a loan.   
 
33. 
Enhancing the institutional capacity of the SBP and Government authorities will also be 
important for the sector. Training of SBP officers in new management  information systems for 
on-site and off-site surveillance and in applications of new technologies and systems for money 
transfer and remittances will help to build capacity for an expanding sector. Within the provincial 
governments  and  at  the  local  district  level,  training  for  automated  land  registration,  records 
systems, and reporting will also be needed to facilitate access to records required by financial 
institutions.

34.   Significant external assistance has been provided by funding agencies to support poverty 
reduction and to accelerate development of the financial sector. A development coordination matrix 
is  included  in  Appendix  4.  Assistance  to  Pakistan’s  financial  sector  includes  support  (debt  and 
equity)  to  retail  institutions  for  expanding  outreach  in  microcredit,  new  product  development, 
microleasing  operations  and  research  for  more  client-responsive  financial  services.  In  terms  of 
support for retail microfinance, the World Bank is supporting the Pakistan Poverty Alleviation Fund 
($360 million), an apex institution that funds civil society institutions in areas of microcredit, small-
scale community infrastructure and capacity building support, including operational assistance. The 
International Finance Corporation (IFC) has provided equity support to two licensed microfinance

technology-based

financial  viability.30  Information  on  the  CGAP  fund  and  application  forms  for  proposals  were 
distributed  in  October  2006  at  the  seminar  “Improving  Access  to  Financial  Services:  Mobile

D. 

Lessons Identified 

36. 
Experience  of  ADB-supported  reform  programs  in  microfinance,  rural  finance,  SME 
finance,  and  non-bank  financial  institutions31  all  highlight  the  importance  of  Government 
institutions  as  facilitators  and  enablers  but  the  need  for  provision  of  services  to  be  left  to 
financially  viable  private  sector  institutions.  Consultative  and  participatory  processes  should 
precede  any  policy  development  if  the  policy  is  to  have  broad  ownership  and  buy-in  from  all 
stakeholders. Targeted subsidies by the government or sponsored institutions should be strictly 
limited  to  situations  where  market  failure  prevents  delivery  through  the  private  sector  (e.g.,  in 
difficult  terrain  or  where  the  client  base  is  widely  disbursed).  In  terms  of  demand,  all  financial 
products  must  be  demand-driven.  Finally,  rigorous  controls,  transparent  policies,  and  good 
business  ethics  must  be  established  and  enforced.  It  should  also  be  noted  that  statutory 
institutions that are created as development vehicles are at risk of being influenced over time by 
other priorities or agendas of Government, even when the shares of the institution are majority 
held by the private sector.  Such influence can divert attention and focus away from the original 
core mandate, and undermine the frameworks and plans established at the outset as appears to 
be the case with the KB created under the earlier microfinance program.32 Lessons learned from 
ADB’s microfinance operations33 are similar to those experienced by other funding agencies and

reported  in  the  Consultative  Group  to  Assist  the  Poor  (CGAP)  guidelines  and  papers.  In 
particular,  the  financial  system  approach  is  the  key  to  achieving  sustainable  results  and  to 
maximizing development impact. This approach emphasizes an enabling policy environment, a 
strong  financial  infrastructure,  and  financial  intermediaries  that  are  committed  to  achieving 
financial  viability  and  sustainability  within  a  reasonable  period  and  can  provide  a  variety  of 
financial services, not just credit, to the poor.   
 
A study of Pakistan’s microfinance policy in 200634 noted that the Government’s catalytic 
37. 
role in the start-up phase had been a success, and that it was now time for the Government to 
step  back  and  let  the  microfinance  industry  evolve  under  its  own  momentum.  The  study 
emphasized that the Government no longer needed to be a provider of microfinance services, 
nor  did  it  need  to  take  an  interventionist  approach  to  the  services  provided.  The  key  role  of 
microfinance  policies  at  this  stage  is  to  provide  an  enabling  environment  for  microfinance 
services provided by institutions that are financially sustainable, or can become sustainable in a 
very  short  time.  The  study  observed  that  development  was  undermined  when  subsidies  were 
passed straight to the borrower in the form of lower interest rates, and/or by subsidies that are 
used by MFIs to avoid the need to establish lending services in order to build adequate capital. 
     

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

38. 
The goal of the proposed Program is to assist the Government to reduce poverty, build 
an  inclusive  financial  sector,  and  promote  sustainable  economic  growth  by  using  technology 
and applications to lower the cost of delivery of financial services and to improve the efficiency 
of  these  services.  The  program’s  objective  is  to  ensure  access  to  sustainable  institutional 
financial  services  for  most  poor  and  low-income  households  and  their  microenterprises  at 
competitive prices. The program will support the Government to improve the performance and 
efficiencies of the financial sector; promote diversification and innovation in product and service 
delivery;  and  increase  outreach  in  rural  and  remote  areas.  Private  sector  participation  and 
innovation in the delivery of products and services will be supported including savings services, 
transfer remittance services, and products and services that are Sharia (Islamic Law) compliant. 
Increased access to a range of financial services on a sustainable basis will enable the poor to 
engage in income generating activities, thereby reducing poverty and vulnerability. It will support 
the Government’s core reforms to increase access and accelerate growth nationwide, including 
programs for literacy.         
 
B. 

Policy Framework and Actions 

The  policy  framework  and  actions  that  have  been  agreed  with  the  Government  are 

39. 
described in Appendix 3. The key measures are as follows. 
 

1. 

Development of Policy, Legal, and Regulatory Frameworks 

Reforms  will  be  undertaken  to  support  more  rapid  growth  and  outreach  of  financial 
40. 
services  to  the  poor,  including  in  rural  and  remote  areas.  A  fundamental  policy  shift  from  the 
previous model based on supply-led credit and subsidies that has led to sector overdependence 
on donor funds credit to a model that is demand-driven and market-oriented will support private

sector participation and the growth of a sustainable financial services sector. The shift in focus 
from emphasis on a statutory institution to more balanced sector-wide support and development 
will also promote a more robust and competitive financial market. Cabinet approval of a draft bill 
to  ensure  that  all  MFBs,  including  KB,  are  licensed  and  operating  under  the  same  legal  and 
regulatory framework, and MOF submission of the draft bill to Parliament for enactment will be a 
key  measure  supported  by  the  program  to  create  an  integrated  legal  framework  for  all 
microfinance banks and equitable treatment for financial institutions seeking to provide services 
to the poor. The Program will also support the Government’s development of a national strategy 
for an inclusive financial sector that integrates efforts in various sub-sectors and encompasses 
all types of financial institutions, including commercial banks, microfinance banks, rural support 
programs, and other NGOs. It will take a medium- and long-term view of sector integration and 
the mainstreaming of the poor in the financial services sector.    
 
41.  Measures  to  support  NGOs  that  want  to  transform  themselves  into  formal  financial 
institutions will be supported. The transformation of NGOs and rural support programs (RSPs) 
into  microfinance  banks  will  help  to  expand  the  number  of  institutions  that  can  provide  a  full 
range  of  financial  products  and  services,  including  savings  and  deposit  services  and 
remittances,  to  the  poor.  SBP  guidelines  have  been  issued  to  support  NGOs  transforming 
themselves into formal financial institutions. SBP will also provide capacity building and evaluate 
such  institutions,  and  review  its  guidelines.  The  program  will  support  the  establishment  and 
development  of  an  on-site  and  off-site  surveillance  capacity  for  SBP  for  microfinance 
institutions.  This  will  help  to  ensure  effective  oversight  and  will  require  staff  training.  IT  and 
system software design will be approved and made operational for these surveillance systems. 
Under  the  Program,  SBP  will  issue  guidelines  for  banks  regarding  access  to  credit  and 
computerized Fard/E Pass books.  
 
42. 
To support the mainstreaming of microfinance and the development of wider distribution 
channels  for  financial  services  for  the  poor,  SBP  guidelines  have  been  issued  to  support 
commercial  banks  to  undertake  microfinance  business  activities.  In  addition,  basic  banking 
accounts (minimum initial deposit of PRs1000, no minimum balance) have been introduced by 
all commercial banks to extend their reach to low-income families and the poor. The Program 
will  support  Government  measures  to  rationalize  tax  incentives  to  promote  mobile  money 
transfers,  mobile  banking,  and  the  use  of  related  technology  and  applications  for  expanded 
nationwide  outreach  of  financial  services.    Current  import  taxes  on  technology  hardware  are 
high  (up  to  20%),  presenting  a  barrier  to  firms’  applications  of  technology  for  growth  and 
economic  development.  As  microfinance  services  and  mobile  banking  operations  expand  to 
provincial  areas,  a  clear  and  consistent  tax  policy  should  support  expansion  and  eliminate 
uncertainties as to cost, ad hoc demands, or extended delays in implementation due to court or 
other  actions.  A  Central  Bureau  of  Revenue  (CBR)  amendment  to  CBR  Notification  S.R.O. 
575(I)/2006 will be issued to allow financial services providers to take advantage of (i) a reduced 
rate of import taxes of 5% and (ii) a sales tax exemption on technology hardware identified by 
the State Bank of Pakistan-Ministry of Information Technology (MOIT) working group to promote 
accelerated  applications  of  modern  technologies.  This  will  ensure  that  financial  services 
providers enjoy the same benefits as other service sectors in the adoption of key technologies. 
MOF will also issue a policy statement encouraging provincial and district authorities to provide 
consistent  tax  treatment  with  respect  to  mobile  banking  operations35  to  promote  national 
outreach and entry into rural areas.

for financing by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, will support pilot tests for mobile banking in Pakistan. 

 

  

17

The  Program  will  support  the  Sindh  government  to  establish  an  automated  land 
43. 
registration and records management system to improve the quality and security of land records 
to improve access to credit and investor confidence. A pilot scheme for the computerization of 
Revenue  Management  Information  System  (REMIS)  will  be  implemented  by  the  Board  of 
Revenue  of  Sindh  Government  in  five  districts:  Hyderabad,  Mirpurkhas,  Sukkur,  Khaipur,  and 
Larkana  (covering  2,146  land  registers.)  The  Board  of  Revenue  of  Sindh  Government  will 
extend REMIS to the remaining 18 districts of Sindh Province to improve transparency in record 
keeping;  promote  secure,  reliable  and  accountable  transactions;  improve  the  quality  of 
ownership and title records; expedite the resolution of land-based disputes; and facilitate access 
to credit and investment. 
 

2. 

Capacity Building and Institutional Strengthening/Restructuring  

44. 
Credit  Information  Bureau  (CIB)  coverage  will  be  expanded  under  the  Program  to 
include  all  types  of  financial  service  providers  (regulated  and  unregulated)  including  MFIs, 
MFBs, NGOs, RSPs, and others). A lack of reliable business information and credit history has 
been  a  major  impediment  to  the  financing  of  microenterprises  and  households.  A  bureau 
covering all types of financial service providers will support increased access to credit promote 
competition  and  increase  financing  options  for  many  borrowers.  A  feasibility  study  of  a  credit 
information  bureau  covering  all  types  of  financial  service  providers  in  rural  and  remote  areas, 
will be undertaken by SBP in cooperation with the Pakistan Microfinance Network (PMN). A pilot 
CIB will be launched by SBP and PMN in accordance with relevant law. 
 
45. 
The  Program  will  support  the  deployment  of  technologies  and  applications  and  the 
removal  of  obstacles  for  mobile  money  transfer  and  remittances  for  lower-cost  and  efficient 
delivery of services nationwide.  An industry forum has been conducted by SBP co-sponsored 
by  ADB  for  banks,  microfinance  institutions,  exchange  companies,  telecommunications  firms, 
and  others  on  mobile  money  transfer,  VSAT,  and  other  technologies  for  improving  access  to 
financial  services.  The  forum  provided  a  good  regional  information  exchange,  including 
presentations from experts on current technology and systems in the Philippines. An SBP-MOIT 
Working Group comprising senior representatives will examine issues affecting the introduction 
of mobile money transfer and technologies. MOIT will issue, as necessary, rules and regulations 
to support technical implementation of mobile money transfers and remittances, including VSAT 
and  other  technologies  based  upon  SBP  plan  and  recommendations.  SBP  will  develop  and 
submit to MOIT a plan for options for establishment of an integrated national platform for mobile 
money  transfer  for  many  users  (e.g.,  banks,  microfinance  banks,  NGOs,  telecommunications 
firms,  and  exchange  companies)  for  lower-cost  and  more  efficient  delivery  of  services 
nationwide.  Pakistan  Telecommunications  Authority  (PTA)  will  rationalize  registration  annual 
license fees on VSAT and other technologies to support applications if technology for outreach 
of financial services. 
 
46. 
The  Program  will  increase  the  capacities  of  financial  services  providers  to  apply 
technologies and systems for mobile money transfer, VSAT and other technologies. To support 
technological  developments,  the  Program  will  establish  an  endowment  fund  to  complement 
capacity building activities of the CGAP worldwide technology fund. An endowment fund in the 
amount  of  $20  million  equivalent  will  be  established  at  the  SBP.  The  income  account  of  the 
endowment  fund  will  be  used  to  fund  training  and  capacity  building  for  (i)  microfinance  banks 
(national, regional, and district) that currently operate in or will expand into rural and remote areas; 
(ii)  new  technologies  and  applications,  including  mobile  money  transfer  and  VSAT  technologies 
for  improved  access  to  financial  services  in  rural  and  remote  areas;  (iii) literacy  (financial  and 
basic)  programs  for  potential  clients;  and  (iv)  training  of  government  authorities,  and  SBP,  to 

 

 18 

 

support the development of an inclusive financial sector and implementation of the Program. SBP 
quarterly reports on capacity building and training activities supported under the endowment fund 
and  list  of  recipients  will  be  posted  on  the  SBP  public  website,  and  an  ADB  observer  will  be 
appointed  to  the  fund  governing  body.  The  institutional  capacity  of  financial  institutions  will  be 
strengthened, especially financial institutions operating in rural areas or with plans to expand into 
rural areas. This will include microfinance banks, NGOs transforming into microfinance banks, and 
commercial banks expanding services to the poor. Training will be provided in credit management 
and delinquency management practices; accounting for bad debts; and provisioning in income.  In 
addition  to  capacity  building  of  financial  institutions,  enhancing  the  institutional  capacity  of 
authorities, including SBP, will be undertaken. Training of SBP officers will cover implementation 
of new systems for on-site and off-site surveillance, and training in applying new technologies and 
systems for mobile money transfer and remittances.   
 
47. 
Restructuring  and  strengthening  of  KB  will  also  be  undertaken  under  the  Program  and 
monitored  by  SBP  to  ensure  it  can  deliver  sustainable  financial  services  efficiently  and  cost-
effectively.  SBP  will  provide  directions  to  KB  on  sustainable  operations  and  best  banking 
practices. KB’s strategy and 5-year operational plan will be approved by SBP and implemented 
through 2008. The bank will also issue an analysis of its low client retention rate (30%) followed 
by  an  action  plan  to  improve  client  services  and  retention.  Following  enactment  of  the  law  to 
bring all MFBs under the same legal and regulatory framework, SBP will license KB as an MFB.  
MOF/National  Bank  of  Pakistan  will  commence  divestiture  of  its  shareholding  in  KB,  and  the 
offer will remain opened during the program period, unless shares are sold at an earlier date.  

 
3. 

Product Diversification and Innovation 

48. 
The Program will support the diversification of the financial services sector in Pakistan. A 
full range of services, including savings, remittances, and other services, is needed to support 
the  economic  activities  and  development  of  rural  households  and  the  poor.  Innovation  and 
alternative financing for rural households will be supported. A task force36 has been established 
by  SBP  to  promote  research  and  development  in  Islamic  banking,  and  draft  guidelines  and 
regulations  will  be  prepared  by  SBP  to  support  the  provision  of  Islamic  microfinance  services 
and products through multiple channels by Islamic banks, commercial banks, and microfinance 
banks.  SBP  will  also  issue  regulations  and  guidelines  to  support  MFBs’  applications  of  such 
technologies  as  mobile  money  transfer  via  cell-phone-  based  technology  and  VSAT  systems. 
Feasibility  studies  will  be  undertaken  on  (i)  the  potential  for  an  Islamic  finance  institute  in 
Pakistan,  (ii)  national  VSAT  applications  and  other  technology  options  to  expand  access  to 
financial  services  in  rural  areas;  and  (iii)  carbon  credits  (grant)  financing37  for  households  and 
the poor. It is important to note that during the life of the Program, banks in Pakistan can also 
apply for an ADB guarantee for their funding lines to support new banking operations, or for the 
expansion of existing operations in connection with Program initiatives for improving access to 
financial services.38          
 
49.  
The  Program  will  support  SBP  actions  to  facilitate  low-cost,  safe  and  speedy 
transmission of remittances from overseas workers to Pakistan. SBP has issued instructions to 
commercial  banks  to  establish  and  make  fully  operational  a  “home  remittance  cell”  with 
dedicated professional staff, including IT experts, and banks will approve and submit an annual

strategic  plan  for  the  mobilization  of  remittances.  A  draft  bill  amending  the  Microfinance 
Institutions Ordinance 2001, or setting forth the necessary provision(s) in the relevant law, will 
be approved by the Cabinet and submitted by MOF to Parliament for enactment to allow MFBs 
to receive remittances directly from overseas workers. 
 
50. 
The  Program  will  support  the  development  of  public–private  partnerships  between 
Pakistan  Post  and  private  sector  financial  institutions  in  order  to  increase  outreach  in  rural 
areas. Such partnerships will enable the national postal infrastructure to provide a full range of 
financial  services  in  rural  and  remote  areas.  Pakistan  Post’s  network  of  12,267  post  offices 
nationwide  can  provides  a  foundation  for  small  institutions  to  expand  rapidly  with  minimal 
investment.  Post  offices’  knowledge  of  the  community  and  the  postmen’s  relationships  with 
people  are  also  invaluable  assets  in  working  toward  greater  rural  outreach  to  the  poor.  The 
partnership arrangements will complement existing savings and other services of Pakistan Post. 
A strategic partnership framework and model agreements will be prepared by Pakistan Post, in 
consultation  with  financial  institutions.  Postal  branches  will  be  identified  by  Pakistan  Post  for 
initial partnerships and pilot schemes, and partnerships will be offered to the private sector. 
 

4. 

Financial and Basic Literacy  

51. 
The Program will support improvements to national literacy and education as a means of 
improving access to financial services for the poor and for rural households. An endowment fund 
will be established at SBP to support financial services providers that conduct literacy programs 
and training for clients and potential clients, either directly themselves or through subcontractors. 
The  endowment  fund  will  be  established  in  the  amount  of  $20  million  equivalent  as  referenced 
above.  SBP  quarterly  reports  on  capacity  building  and  training  activities  supported  under  the 
endowment  fund  and  list  of  recipients  will  be  posted  on  the  SBP  public  website  and  an  ADB 
observer will be appointed to the governing body of the fund.   
 
C. 

Financing Plan 

52. 
It  is  proposed  that  ADB  support  the  Government’s  policy  reforms  under  the  Improving 
Access to Financial Services Program with two loans. The Borrower will be the Islamic Republic 
of  Pakistan.  The  loans  are  (i)  a  loan  of  $300  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources 
(OCR), with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.75% per annum, a term of 15 years 
including a grace period of 3 years, and such other terms and conditions as set forth in the loan 
agreement; and (ii) a loan of Special Drawing Rights 13,425,000 ($20,000,000 equivalent) from 
ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources,  with  an  interest  rate  of  1.0%  per  annum  during  the  grace 
period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, a term of 24 years, including a grace period of 8 years, 
and such other terms and conditions as set forth in the loan agreement. With respect to the first 
loan,  the  Government  has  provided  ADB  with  (i)  the  reasons  for  its  decision  to  borrow  under 
ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility  on  the  basis  of  these  terms  and  conditions,  and  (ii)  an 
undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not made in reliance on 
any communication or advice from ADB. 
   
53. 
The  following  factors  were  taken  into  account  in  determining  the  loan  size:  the 
importance of improving access to financial services for economic growth and poverty reduction, 
the strength of the program, the financial and institutional costs associated with implementing it, 
and  the  Government’s  overall  financing  needs.  The  program  proceeds  will  help  create  fiscal 
space for the Government to meet the financing requirements for earthquake reconstruction and 
other expenditures for the social sector. Associated program costs include a reduction in import 

 

 20 

 

taxes  and  an  exemption  from  the  sales  tax  on  technology  hardware  and  components;  the 
removal  of  other  obstacles  to  the  deployment  of  technology,  such  as  high  registration  and 
licensing  fees;  capacity  building  of  Government  authorities  and  agencies;  and  institutional 
strengthening and restructuring of institutions.  
 
D. 

Implementation Arrangements 

54.  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  will  be  the  Executing  Agency.  The  financial  management 
arrangements  are  assessed  as  adequate.  Accumulated  experience  in  implementing  a  large 
number  of  program  loans  demonstrates  MOF’s  proven  competence  and  capacity  to  effectively 
carry out the financial management of the Program. Implementing Agencies will be State Bank of 
Pakistan  (SBP);  Central  Bureau  of  Revenue  (CBR);  Ministry  of  Information  Technology  (MOIT); 
Pakistan Post (PP); and the Board of Revenue of Sindh Government. A program coordination and 
implementation unit (PCIU) will be established in Islamabad at the MOF for program coordination, 
monitoring and management across agencies. Working groups will also be established to include 
all Implementing Agencies for a good collaboration, communication and timely implementation of 
measures  under  the  program.  In  addition  to  the  PCIU,  SBP  will  provide  office  facilities  for 
consultants in Karachi to facilitate coordination and the oversight of consultants. The PCIU will be 
responsible  to  provide  the  required  program  reports  and  information  for  implementation  of  the 
program.  Establishment of the PCIU will be a condition for loan negotiations.   
 
55. 
To assess the impact of the program on poverty, existing data from Federal Bureau of 
Statistics, Pakistan’s official statistical organization, will be used. The Pakistan Social and Living 
Standards  Measurement  (PSLM)  survey  provides  key  social  indicators  at  national,  provincial 
and district levels. A household integrated economic survey (a component of the PSLM survey) 
provides  important  data  on  household  income,  consumption  expenditure  and  patterns  at  the 
national  level,  with  a  rural–urban  breakdown.  The  information  on  household  income  and 
expenditure  is  used  by  Centre  for  Research  on  Poverty  Reduction  and  Income  Distribution  to 
estimate  poverty  levels.  In  addition,  the  Pakistan  Microfinance  Network  (PMN)  publishes 
performance  measures  and  standards  related  to  the  work  of  retail  microfinance  providers. 
Members  of  PMN  include  microfinance  banks,  NGOs  that  are  specialized  microfinance 
institutions,  NGOs  running  microfinance  operations  as  a  part  of  their  integrated  development 
in 
programs, 
microfinance.  Published  data  include  the  number  of  active  borrowers,  the  gross  loan  portfolio, 
and outstanding loans for female clients. The State Bank of Pakistan also collects data on the 
banking sector, which will be used to assess the program impacts.

ADB's policy document Anticorruption (1998, as amended to date), was explained to and 
57. 
discussed  with  the  Government.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability,  and  transparency,  ADB  reserves  the  right  to  investigate,  directly  or  through  its 
agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the Program. To 
support  these  efforts,  relevant  provisions  of  ADB's  Anticorruption  document  are  included  in  the 
loan regulations. The National AntiCorruption Strategy (NACS), introduced in Pakistan in 2002, is 
being  implemented  under  the  guidance  of  the  National  Accountability  Bureau.  The  strategy  and 
implementation  plan  is  consistent  with  the  ADB  and  OECD  Anti-Corruption  Initiative  for  Asia-
