sector  management,  development,  procurement  and  contracting,  financial  management,  public 
accountability bodies, anticorruption agencies, legal system and judiciary, media, civil society and 
the private sector. The Government is undertaking reforms at the federal level in budgeting and 
fiscal monitoring, including submission of funding proposals based on objectives and a medium-
term budgeting framework. The World Bank’s Project to Improve Financial Reporting and Auditing 
(PIFRA)  seeks  to  address  weaknesses  in  accounting  and  audit,  including  the  introduction  of  a 
new  accounting  model  that  is  consistent  with  international  best  practice.  There  are  fiscal 
monitoring  committees  at  federal  and  provincial  levels  and  the  Government  publishes  federal 
quarterly  fiscal  accounts  on  its  website.  The  Auditor  General’s  Department  is  following 
International  Organization  of  Supreme  Audit  Institutions  (INTOSAI)  best  practices  in  its  reform 
agenda. 
 
F. 

Counterpart Funds 

58. 
Counterpart  funds  will  be  used  for  the  financial  and  institutional  costs  associated  with 
implementing  the  reform  program  and  other  development  financing  needs.  The  entire 
counterpart funds of the $20 million equivalent from ADB’s Special Funds resources loan shall 
be transferred as a capital contribution to the Improving Access to Financial Services Fund, an 
endowment  fund  to  be  established  to  support  (i)  capacity  building  and  training  of  financial 
services  providers  to  promote    expansion  into  rural  areas;  product  and  service  innovation, 
including  savings,  remittances  and  Islamic  financial  services;  adoption  and  integration  of  new 
technologies  and  applications  for  improving  access  to  financial  services;  (ii) capacity  building 
and  training  of  Government  and  regulatory  authorities  to  support  development  of  an  inclusive 
financial sector and implementation of measures under the Program; and (iii) literacy programs 
(financial  and  basic)  conducted  by  or  on  behalf  of  financial  services  providers  for  clients  and 
potential clients to improve access to financial services and the utilization of finance. 
 
G. 

Monitoring and Tranching 

59. 
The  expected  program  completion  date  is  24  months  from  effectiveness  (expected 
December  2006).  The  program  loan  closing  is  expected  3  months  after  program  completion. 
The  loan  will  be  released  in  two  tranches.  The  first  tranche  of  $120  million  equivalent  will  be 
made available when the Government has satisfied loan effectiveness and first tranche release 
conditions.  The  first  tranche  will  comprise  $100  million  from  the  OCR  of  ADB  and  $20 million 
equivalent  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources.  The  second  tranche  of  $200  million  will  be 
from  OCR,  is  expected  to  be  released  within  24  months  of  loan  effectiveness,  and  will  be 
released upon satisfactory compliance with the agreed upon conditions.  
 
H. 

Subsequent Program/Phase II  

60. 
The Government’s Improving Access to Financial Services (Phase I) Program will focus 
on measures pertaining to the development and mainstreaming of microfinance in the financial 

 

 22 

 

sector and the implementation of strategic cross-cutting measures to increase national outreach 
of sustainable financial services across a range of financial services providers. The Government 
plans to further develop financial services in phase II to address second generation reforms to 
support  other  deprived  segments  of  the  economy  like,  SMEs,  agricultural  finance,  and  other 
areas which would ultimately lead to an integrated financial system capable of meeting the fast 
growing requirements of every segment of the economy over the long-term. The Government is 
adopting a sequenced approach with the initial focus on critical constraints considered under the 
present program.

VI. 

PROGRAM, BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

 

A. 

Benefits and Impact on Poverty 

The  IAFSP  will  provide  many  benefits  and  will  have  positive  impacts  nationwide, 

63. 
including for the poor and rural households.  Some of the key benefits include: 

a  deeper/broader  financial  sector  that  fosters  inclusive  economic  growth  and  
reduces poverty, and a sustainable market-oriented microfinance sector with greater 
outreach to the poor in rural and urban areas; 
an  enabling  regulatory  and  supervisory  framework  that  promotes  innovation  and 
product diversification and private sector participation; 
improved credit information and land registration systems to provide information for 
access to and delivery of credit; 
removal  of  operational  bottlenecks  and  constraints  among  intermediaries,  including 
those  inhibiting  a  new  and  a  broader  range  of  services,  and  new  technologies  and 
applications, such as mobile money transfer and very small aperture terminal (VSAT) 
technologies to improve access to financial services in rural and remote areas;  
increased  opportunities  for  all  types  of  clients,  including  better  systems  and 
procedures for remittances and Islamic finance; and 
increased literacy (financial and basic) among clients and potential clients, leading to 
improved access to and utilization of financial services.

C. 

Risks 

The success of the IAFSP depends upon a number of assumptions that are subject to 
65. 
different degrees of risk. Mitigating measures have been put in place. The primary risks are as 
follows.  
 

Commitment  to  reform  may  wane.  Building  a  more  inclusive  financial  sector 
requires  a  continued  commitment  to  sector  reforms.  Although  a  lessening  of 
commitment  is  a  risk,  the  Government  has  shown  strong  commitment  to 
achieving  the  goals  of  the  Program,  as  reflected  in  its  MTDF  2005-2010,  its 
poverty reduction strategy and investment and expenditure programs focusing on 
the poor (pursuant to the Fiscal Responsibility and Debt Limitation Act , 2005).   
Delays  or  disruptions  may  occur  because  of  political  instability  or  social  unrest. 
These risks, and the international perception of such risks, are moderate to low. 
A  buyer  or  buyers  willing  to  pay  a  fair  market  price  within  the  specified  time 
period for shares in KB held by the National Bank of Pakistan may not be found. 
To  mitigate  this  risk  and  promote  competition,  the  offer  for  sale  of  shares  will 
remain open during the program period.  
Funds  from  the  endowment  fund  may  not  be  allocated  on  a  balanced  basis 
across  financial  services  providers,  authorities  and  geographic  areas.  To 
increase  transparency  and  disclosure  of  fund  allocations,  quarterly  reports  on 
recipients and activities funded will be posted on the SBP website, and an ADB 
nominee will be appointed to the endowment fund as an observer.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 

1. 
The development of microfinance and the mainstreaming of microfinance in the financial 
sector  are  essential  elements  of  building  an  inclusive  financial  sector  with  national  outreach. 
The microfinance sector in Pakistan is recognized as still in early stages of development. The 
issuance  of  Khusshali  Bank  Ordinance  in  2000  and  the  Microfinance  Institutions  Ordinance  in 
20011  provided  the  basic  legal  framework  for  establishment  of  microfinance  banks  and  a 
regulated  microfinance sector.  It is estimated  that  40  MFIs  currently  operate  in  Pakistan,2  and 
that  19  institutions  account  for  almost  99%  of  the  microfinance  market.  This  includes  the  6 
licensed microfinance banks, and 13 other MFIs that are members of the Pakistan Microfinance 
Network (PMN). PMN issues comprehensive reports for annual performance indicators tracking 
the  developments  and  performance  of  microfinance  banks,  rural  support  programs  and  other 
NGO-MFIs.  For purposes of this RRP the term  microfinance finance institutions (MFIs) will be 
used to broadly refer to all types of institutions providing microfinance. Table 1 below provides a 
list of the 19 primary institutions providing microfinance services.

access to microfinance in Pakistan is generally considered due to the constraints on mobility of 
females,  especially  in  the  rural  areas,  and  other  cultural  constraints.  The  fact  that  other  MFIs 
have, however, achieved a higher rate of women access than MFBs, may indicate that the non-
financial  services  provided  by  the  MFIs  have  played  an  important  role  in  the  mobilization  and 
access  of  women.  It  is  also  recognized  that  institutions  with  a  primary  mandate  to  service 
women, such as Kashf Foundation, have demonstrated successful in reaching women including 
in rural areas. This indicates a need on the part of MFBs to adopt and/or adapt some portion of 
operations in order to tap the women’s market. Table 2 below provides comparative data on the

Unregulated  MFIs  are  not  allowed  to  take  voluntary  deposits,  as  they  are  outside  the 
3. 
SBP  regulatory  framework  which  provides  the  necessary  measures  and  oversight  for 
institutional soundness and safety to deposits. Unfortunately, licensed MFBs have been slow to 
provide this important service to clients, and have concentrated on credit as the primary service. 
This  disparity  is  clearly  seen  in  the  data  as  the  total  number  of  depositors  at  MFBs  was  only 
37,245 (or about 14.7% of the number of borrowers). The reliance on subsidized credits and the 
negative  impact  on  mobilizing  deposits  and  the  development  of  a  sustainable  microfinance 
market have been earlier discussed in the Sector Description and Performance. Although four 
hold licenses to operate nationwide, efforts have concentrated on the district of Karachi. With an 
estimated  population  of  over  12  million,  the  Karachi  district  continues  to  represent  a  vast 
potential market for MFBs. 

An  examination  of  microfinance  loans  by  sector,  shows  a  rural  focus  of  MFB 
4. 
microfinance services with 65% of outstanding loans for agri-inputs and livestock. The SBP data 
for  microfinance  loans  by  sector  are  classified  into  four  main  categories:  agri-input  (41%); 
enterprise  loans  (26%);  livestock  (24%);  and  other  purposes  (9%).  Figure  1  shows  the 
breakdown  as  of  31  March  2005.    Although  an  increase  in  both  rural  and  urban  microfinance 
services are expected in the coming years, rural microfinance services will continue to dominate 
with 68% of the population in rural areas.

5. 
To expand services in the rural areas, exploration of options for mobile money transfers 
using  cell-phone  based  technology  can  play  an  important  role  as  earlier  discussed.  The 
introduction  of  innovative  services  such  as  electronic  and  mobile  banking  to  leverage  the 
substantial  reach  of  mobile  phone  services  is  now  ripe  for  Pakistan.  The  telecom  sector  in 
Pakistan has grown to a level where such services could be launched conveniently to benefit a 
large segment of the population currently hooked on to the mobile phone network. The Pakistan 
Telecommunications  Authority  (PTA)  has  reported  a  rapidly  increasing  subscriber  base  from 
306,493 in 2000 to over 36 million subscribers as of July 2006. The top firm accounts for 50% of 
mobile cellular subscribers, and the top two firm together account for 71% of total subscribers. 
Despite such concentrated market shares, the industry is considered as robust and competitive. 
Mobilink,  a  subsidiary  of  Orascom  Telecom,  started  operations  in  1994  and  is  the  largest 
operator in Pakistan. Mobilink was the first cellular service provider to operate on a 100% digital 

 

 

 

  
30 

Appendix 1 

GSM technology in Pakistan, and currently provides the widest network with coverage of 1000 
cities, towns, and villages in Punjab, Sindh, Balochista, North-West Frontier Province (NWFP), 
Capital,  and  Azad  Jammu  and  Kashmir.4    Other  operators  services  cover  between  100-  500 
cities each, two of the operators are subsidiaries of major European operators,5 and Warid Tel is 
backed by the Abu Dhabi Group, one of the largest groups in the Middle East.6 
 
6. 
Deregulation  in  the  telecom  sector  has  supported  the  entry  of  new  players  and  new 
technologies,  along  with  higher  service  levels  and  lower  prices  for  consumers  throughout  the 
country.    As  part  of  the  technological  revolution  in  the  telecom  sector,  PTCL  will  provide  2.1 
million  new  wireless  local  loop  (WLL)  telephone  connections  in  remote  and  rural  areas  of  the 
country. The completion of the WLL facility is expected to take the phone coverage, presently 
around 30% in Pakistan to the level of 100%.7  Such access will support economic activity and 
boost  ongoing  productive  activities  in  both  the  industrial  and  agriculture  sectors.  Farmers  will 
have better access to market information and markets for agriculture-produce, reducing the role 
of middlemen and increasing opportunities for better pricing to farmers. The rapid advancement 
of communication technology at affordable rates will be an important factor in reducing poverty, 
especially in rural areas. The utilization of technology to also facilitate financial services to the 
poor  and  rural  communities  will  also  be  key  for  improving  access  to  financial  services  in  this 
decade.   

Mobile  banking  facility  is  in  place  in  many  developing  countries  consisting  of 
7. 
comprehensive banking services including money transfer, cash-in, cash-out, person to person 
transfer,  bill  payments,  on-line  purchases  etc.  Mobile  phone  banking  services  have  been 
successfully  launched  in  various  countries,  including  the  Philippines,  where  it  offers  the 
consumers  a  virtual  wallet  providing  for  a  convenient  way  of  transferring  and  remitting  funds 
through  SMS.  The  codes  and  messages  exchanged  in  the  process  can  then  be  converted  to 
cash at widely deployed distribution channel locations and even retail outlets. Other developing 
countries  utilizing  mobile  phones  to  access  bank  accounts  include  the  People’s  Republic  of 
China,  Bangladesh  and  India.  In  South  Africa,  20-25%  of  people  who  have  never  had  a  bank 
account  have  access  to  a  mobile  phone.  Through  a  partnership  between  a  bank  and  a 
telecommunication company, it is now possible to use SMS to pay for goods, remit money, have 
salaries  deposited  directly  into  cellular  accounts,  as  well  as  deposit  cash  at  Post  Offices  and 
some  bank  branches.  This  service  is  being  promoted  extensively  in  townships  and  rural 
communities  to  help  un-banked  customers  open  accounts.  Such  product  is  planned  to  be 
expanded to Botswana, Namibia, Zambia, and Malawi. In Kenya, through a partnership between 
a  telecom  company,  a  commercial  bank,  a  microfinance  organization,  and  DFID  (providing 
matching  funding),  microfinance  clients  receive  a  mobile  phone  through  which  they  could 
electronically  make  payments  on  their  loans.  In  addition,  customers  are  able  to  deposit  or 
withdraw  cash  from  authorized  agents,  make  person-to-person  money  transfers,  purchase 
airtime  for  re-sale  or  personal  use,  and  receive  accounts  statements.  Other  options  to  get 
connectivity  into  rural  areas  include  fixed  wireless  technology  (WiFi,  WiMax)  and  a  new 
generation of satellite networks (VSAT). These enable the transmission of voice traffic through 
the internet. Such application has been applied in Viet Nam and Mongolia.

Technology  solutions,  such  as  the  internet  and  mobile  phone,  also  hold  considerable 
8. 
promise for increasing access to improved and less costly services for remittance senders and 
receivers,  including  those  in  remote  or  underserved  areas.  The  potential  impact  is  vast  for 
Pakistan  where  workers  remittances  are  estimated  at  more  than  $9  billion  through  formal  and 
informal channels. This is particularly so for Sri Lanka where migrant worker remittance is the 
country’s  highest  foreign  exchange  earner.  Nearly  60%  of  migrant  worker  remittance  comes 
from rural Sri Lankan women who have been working abroad. A local bank has developed an 
innovative  e-product,  the  Money2Home  remittance  service,  which  transfers  funds  from  any 
country to any designated account at any branch of the bank in real time, through the internet. 
The transfer can take place if one is a member of the local bank’s internet banking service, or by 
visiting  an  appointed  money  agent  where  clients  can  obtain  the  same  service  for  a  nominal 
competitive rate. 

9. 
In  implementing  these  new  payment  innovations,  conforming  to  the  national  banking 
regulatory  requirements  including  liquidity,  security,  fraud  detection  and  money  laundering 
prevention, is essential. The issues of fraud detection and money laundering can be managed 
by  tracking  deposit  and  withdrawal  transaction  value  and  patterns.  New  technological 
opportunities also allow the use of tangible objects such as voice, face or fingerprint recognition 
and a password for customer due diligence.

POLICY MATRIX 
 
The goals of the Improving Access to Financial Services (Phase I) Program are to develop a sound and inclusive financial sector that addresses 
the needs of the poor and lower income people on a sustainable basis.  The program will support increased outreach in rural and remote areas 
and  access  of  the  poor  and  women  to  competitively  priced  financial  services  utilizing  new  technologies  and  applications.  Private  sector 
participation and innovation in the delivery of products and services will be supported including savings services, transfers, remittance services, 
and products and services that are Sharia (Islamic Law) compliant. Increased access to financial services on a sustainable basis will enable the 
poor to engage in income generating activities, thereby reducing poverty and vulnerability.

Activities 
In partnership with the Omar Asghar Khan Development 
Foundation in 2005, the Foundation brought together 
Pakistan's leading civil society organizations to create 
the Pakistan Coalition for Overcoming Poverty. As 
Pakistan civil society's first collective effort in pro-poor 
policy reform, the development of this coalition is of 
great strategic importance. The coalition is able to 
promote institutional reform and citizen participation, 
and is well-placed to help the government overcome 
institutional constraints, by providing mechanisms for 
citizen participation in governance, and effectively 
implementing the country's Poverty Reduction Strategy. 
 
Expand Kashf Foundation’s microfinance program to 
reach 300,000 poor women and their families in central 
and southern Punjab, develop innovative demand 
driven products and develop a model for the delivery of 
microfinance services to poor women, which can be 
replicated widely throughout Pakistan. The support is 
expected to end in 2010. 
 
The purpose of this project is to increase poor people 
access to financial services throughout Pakistan. This 
will be done by conducting and disseminating a 
nationwide demand side survey of microfinance looking 
at clients needs and disseminating among financial 
institutions to allow them to tailor products and 
programs to meet market needs. 
 
Funding of the Pakistan Microfinance Network, whose 
members consist of banks, microfinance banks and 
non-government organizations (NGOs). The program 
focuses on influencing policy, raising awareness, 
building capacity and transparency within the sector.

The First MicroFinance Bank Limited (FMFB), a project 
of the Aga Khan Fund for Economic Development 
(AKFED), is a licensed MFI, based in Islamabad, 
Pakistan. FMFB is a full-service, deposit-taking 
institution regulated by the State Bank of Pakistan and 
licensed to operate nationally. Operations are currently 
focused on rural borrowers in the Northern Areas 
(where the bank inherited an AKFED-developed rural 
support program (AKRSP), in operation since 1982). 
FMFB currently has a loan portfolio of approximately 
Rs. 600 million with 35 branches and services units. 
 
TMBL is also a licensed MFI, which focused on urban 
areas. It will extend individual loans up to PRs60000 
(approximately $1000 equivalent) and bring other basic 
financial services, including deposits and life insurance, 
to small entrepreneurs, many of them women. 
 
IFC is also providing technical assistance ($330,000) to 
help design and deploy TMBL’s IT systems to increase 
outreach and improve risk management. Additional 
technical assistance to develop new products, 
strengthening systems and improve efficiencies is 
planned.

Activities 

The overall project strategy to enhance farm 
productivity, household incomes and the social and 
economic development of vulnerable groups in the local 
population would feature the following: (i) strengthening 
of extension services to intensify and diversify crop and 
livestock production systems through adoption of 
appropriate technologies and alternative resource 
management practices; (ii)mobilization of communities 
for self-help and establishment of linkages with the 
public and private sector services for technical 
assistance and input supply; (iii) improvement of access 
of local communities to markets, social services and 
rural infrastructure; (iv) provision of rural savings and 
credit services for on- and off-farm income generation 
activities and micro-enterprises; and (v) capacity 
strengthening and contracting with the line departments 
to provide services required by the communities in a 
participatory mode. 
 
The loan was approved in December 2005. The overall 
objective of the program would enable active rural poor 
to increasingly access a wider range of sustainable 
financial services and products that respond to their 
needs. The program would be an integral part of 
Pakistan Poverty alleviation Fund (PPAF)’s most 
important operation—its credit and enterprise 
development program—and would, through the 
development of new microfinance products and 
services, leverage the sizeable funding already 
available to participating organizations (POs) through 
PPAF’s regular lending program (2.5 million 
beneficiaries to-date). The 180,000 households that are 
projected to directly benefit from program funding 
represent only a portion of the households that would 
ultimately benefit from the program once successful 
products and services are mainstreamed. The program 
will support pilot projects to test and develop new 
microfinance products and services such as livestock 
insurance, equity partnerships, leasing arrangements,

The project helps improve the economic base of the 
rural economies in Chitral, N.W.F.P. with a particular 
focus on women through transformation into sustainable 
private production SME. 
 
The project is aimed at increasing the productivity and 
profitability of micro and small enterprises including 
household businesses through revival of traditional 
crafts and developing other potential enterprise sectors 
in Baltistan and the Northern Areas. 
 
The project helps to improve the access of poor people 
to basic healthcare, primary education and opportunities 
for economic empowerment, and thus sustainable 
livelihoods. The project is also responsible for 
strengthening NGOs and community-based 
organizations focusing on education, healthcare and 
sustainable livelihoods.

1  “Carbon  finance”  represents  a  significant  opportunity  to  direct  private  capital  to  address  rural  poverty  and 
sustainable  energy,  agriculture,  and  forestry.  Kyoto  Protocol  requires  35  industrialized  nations  to  reduce 
Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Emissions below 1990 levels. To meet Kyoto Protocol requirements, developed countries 
are  purchasing  certified  emission  reductions  (CERS)  from  developing  countries  for  carbon  emissions  reductions 
resulting  from  the  establishment  of  new  sustainable  energy  systems.    The  value  of  the  global  trade  in  CERS  is 
currently estimated at $5-10 billion per year. Small projects involving biomass/biogas technologies are among the 
opportunities  for  households  participation.  Countries  in  the  region  are  already  tapping  carbon  finance  at  the 
household level, including Nepal which has an established system providing households with an up-front payment 
in exchange for assigning the rights to the future stream of payments associated with the emissions reductions. In 
addition to providing on-site power, benefits from biomass project include the excess slurry generated that can be 
used as fertilizer on adjacent fields and/or used as fish food for fish farms.

Appendix 7 

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY  

 
A. 

Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 

 
Is the sector identified as a national 
priority in country poverty analysis?

country poverty partnership agreement?   

 

 
 Yes

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
 
The Government’s poverty reduction and strategy paper (PRSP), completed in December 2003, rests on four pillars: (i) 
achieving  high  and  broad-based  economic  growth  focusing  particularly  on  the  rural  economy,  while  maintaining 
macroeconomic stability; (ii) improving governance and consolidating devolution; (iii) investing in human capital with a 
renewed  emphasis  on  effective  delivery  of  basic  social  services;  and  (iv)  bringing  the  poor  and  vulnerable  and 
backward regions into the mainstream of development, and to make marked progress in reducing existing inequalities.  
 
The  first  pillar  comprises  several  policy  and  structural  elements  including:  financial  sector  reform,  capital  market 
development, streamlining the regulatory framework, improving the enabling environment for small and medium-sized 
enterprises (SMEs), the provision of supportive infrastructure, and rural development strategy. 
 
Under  the  fourth  pillar,  the  Government  recognizes  that  microfinance  is  fast  emerging  as  a  viable  tool  to  reduce 
poverty. The Government is keen to promote microfinance activities in the country on a fast track basis. 
 
Poverty  reduction  is  an  encompassing  objective  of  Pakistan’s  Medium  Term  Development  Framework  (MTDF)   
2005-10. The MTDF subsumes the Government’s PRSP issued in 2003. 

 

 
 

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                      Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
The  Pakistan  Economic  Survey  2005–2006,  released  in  June  2006,  reports  that  the  percentage  of  population  living 
below the  poverty  line  has fallen from  34.46% in 2001 to  23.9%  in  2004–2005, a decline of  10.6 percentage  points. 
The  percentage  of  population  living  below  the  poverty  line  in  rural  areas  has  declined  from  39.26%  to  28.10%while 
those  in  urban  areas,  has  declined  from  22.69%  to  14.9%.  Rural  poverty  declined  by  11.16  percentage  points  and 
urban poverty was reduced by 7.79 percentage points. 
 
A  strong  economic  growth  (7.5%  average)  for  3  years  in  a  row,  a  large  inflow  of  remittances  (over  $4  billion  per 
annum)  in  recent  years,  and  many  other  interventions  contributed  to  the  decline  in  poverty.  Notwithstanding  this 
development,  the  fact  remains  that  around  36.45  million  people  in  Pakistan  still  live  below  the  poverty  line.  Further 
reduction in poverty is a major challenge for the Government. 
 
Microfinance plays a critical role in improving the lives of the poor people. The poor use financial services not only for 
business  investment  in  their  micro-enterprises  but  also  to  invest  in  health  and  education,  to  manage  household 
emergencies, and to meet the wide variety of other liquidity needs that they encounter occasionally. Evidence from the 
millions of microfinance clients around the world demonstrate that access to financial services enables poor people to 
increase  their  household  income,  build  assets  and  reduce  their  vulnerability  to  the  crises  that  are  so  much  a  part  of 
their daily lives. 
 
In the context of Pakistan, the use of micro-credit holds importance for both the agricultural and non agricultural sector. 
The need for credit is particularly important for poor farmers. Their requirement for agricultural inputs, seeds, fertilizer, 
pesticide etc. tends to be cyclical as does their income. However the two cycles do not always coincide. Rural loans for 
non agricultural purposes include such things as micro enterprises in unorganized sectors of rural economy. 
 
Realizing  the  importance  of  microfinance  as  a  tool  of  poverty  reduction  and  social  mobilization,  the  Government  is 
accelerating its efforts to establish strong foundations of microfinance in formal sector along with extending support to 
the informal sector. 
 

 

 Appendix 7 

69

In recent years the role of remittances in reducing poverty has been widely acknowledged. Remittances allow families 
to  maintain  or  increase  expenditure  on  basic  consumption,  housing,  education,  and  small-business  formation. 
Remittances  constitute  one  of  the  largest  sources  of  external  finance  for  developing  countries  and  Pakistan  is  no 
exception.  Total  remittances  inflows  since  2001-02  and  until  2005-06  have  amounted  over  $  19  billion  or  Rs.1129 
billion.  It  has  averaged  4.1%of  GDP  during  the  last  four  years.  Such  a  massive  inflow  of  remittances  particularly 
towards the rural or semi-urban areas of Pakistan must have helped loosen the budget constraints of their recipients, 
allowing them to increase consumption of both durables and non-durables, on human capital accumulation (through both 
education and health care), and on real estate. To the extent that the poorer sections of society depend on remittances for 
their  basis  consumption  needs,  increased  flow  of  remittances  would  be  associated  with  reduction  in  poverty  and 
possibly in equality. 
 
The  proposed  Improving  Access  to  Financial  Services  Program  (the  Program)  aims  to  assist  the  Government  to 
reduce  poverty,  build  an  inclusive  financial  sector,  and  promote  sustainable  economic  growth.  Policy,  legal  and 
regulatory reforms will be undertaken to support more rapid growth and outreach of financial services, including in rural 
and  remote  areas  Among  others,  a  National  Strategy  for  Inclusive  Financial  Services  will  be  developed  that  will 
incorporate all types of institutions including commercial banks, microfinance banks, rural support programs and other 
non-government organizations. Development of savings services, insurance, lower cost money transfer and remittance 
services,  and  products  and  services  that  are  shara  (Islamic  Law)  compliant  will  be  supported  to  provide  a 
comprehensive range of financial services, not only credit. Adoption of new technology  and applications for lowering 
cost of remittances will also be supported under the Program and innovation in service delivery to address the limited 
mobility of women, especially in rural areas. To achieve a large outreach in rural and remote areas, the Pakistan Post 
will undertake strategic partnerships with microfinance banks and other financial institutions to provide loans and credit 
services  through  the  postal  network  of  more  than  12,267  post  offices  country  wide.  Strengthening  the  institutional 
capacity  of  financial  institutions  will  be  undertaken  including  for  microfinance  banks,  nongovernment  organizations 
transforming into microfinance banks, and commercial banks  expanding  services to meet the needs of the poor and 
lower  income  families.  In  addition  to  capacity  building  of  financial  institutions,  enhancing  the  institutional  capacity  of 
authorities including the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) and provincial and local authorities will be undertaken. Training 
of SBP officers for implementation of new systems for on-site and off-site surveillance, and training for applications of 
new technologies and systems for money transfer and remittances to lower cost of transfers are among key areas for 
capacity building.

D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Women  in  Pakistan  generally  have  limited  mobility.  They  cannot  fully  participate  in  economic  activities  that  will  help 
generate  more  incomes.  Introducing  mobile  banking  to  the  rural  areas  will  enhance  outreach,  especially  for  women. 
Expansion  of  financial  services  through  partnership  between  the  Pakistan  Post  and  microfinance  banks  and  other 
financial institutions to rural areas will enhance access to financial services by women.

Poverty Impact Analysis 

A. 
 
1. 
During  the  program  period,  a  number  of  benefits  and  impacts  have  been  identified. 
These  include  increased  outreach  of  financial  services  to  about  [2  million]  poor  and  rural 
households,  product  innovation  and  diversification  at  the  micro-level  allowing  those  left  out  of 
conventional micro-credit to benefit from Conventional and Islamic Finance services of savings, 
remittances and, once their debt borrowing capacity is strengthened, micro-loans for productive 
enterprises.  
 
The main focus of the project is also to allow greater accessibility of financial services to 
2. 
women. In order to support this, the project supports and encourages use of mobile and VSAT 
technology  for  greater  financial  services  outreach  and  mobile  banking  operations.  Applying 
these  technologies  would  significantly  lower  the  transaction  costs  of  reaching  the  women  and 
increase their participation in economic activity at the household level. To support women’s role 
in wider economic development, a component dealing with literacy for women has been added. 
Under  this  component,  a  national  level  literacy  campaign  will  be  conducted  to  support  an 
inclusive  financial  sector,  access  of  women  to  financial  services,  and  expanded  outreach  of 
financial services in rural and remote areas. Evidence from Pakistan (and regional experience 
elsewhere)  suggests  that  increasing  women’s’  outreach  to  financial  services  has  resulted  in 
increase  in  household  incomes,  food  consumption,  consumer  durables,  and  generation  of

Funding, Management and Revenue Utilization of the Fund 

 
C. 
 
5. 
The  Fund  will  be  established  for  twenty  years  at  the  State  Bank  of  Pakistan  (SBP)  to 
provide a long-term source of funds for the envisaged literacy programs and capacity building 
initiatives  of  various  stakeholders  including  retailers,  clients  and  potential  clients,  and 
government and regulatory authorities. SBP will have the possession, management and control 
of  the  Fund,  its  undertakings,  properties  and  assets.    Counterpart  funds  (in  Pakistani  rupees) 
generated from the proceeds of the $20 million equivalent Special Funds Resources component 
of the first tranche of IAFSP will be contributed by the Government to the Fund. The Fund will 
be  established  as  an  endowment  fund,  whereby  the  income  generated  from  the  Fund  will  be 
used  for  supporting  the  activities  described  above  on  a  grant  basis,  and  the  initial  $20  million 
equivalent  capital  contribution  will  remain  in  place  for  the  life  of  the  Fund.    The  Fund  will 
establish  its  own  rules,  subject  to  ADB  concurrence,  specifying,  among  other  things,  (i)  the 
selection  criteria  for  the  capacity  building  initiatives  and  literacy  programs  it  will  support, 
including  general  percentage  allocations  to  be  applied  among  the  different  categories  of 
activities; (ii) the investment strategy for the Fund; and (iii) accounting and auditing procedures. 
It  is expected  that  the  initial capital of  the  Fund  and  the  unutilized  income  generated  from  the 
Fund would be invested by SBP in approved government securities. 
 
The  Fund  will  be  administered  and  managed  by  the  governing  body  (the  “Governing 
6. 
Body”)  consisting  of  five  voting  members  and  one  observer.  The  Governing  Body  will  be 
comprised of an SBP Nominee; CEO of Pakistan Poverty Alleviation Fund (PPAF); CEO of the 
Pakistan Microfinance Network; Pakistan Banking Association (PBA) Nominee; a representative 
from  the  education  sector  to  be  nominated  by  the  other  four  voting  members;  and  an  ADB 
Observer  with  non-voting  status.    The  Governing  Body’s  responsibilities  shall  include,  among 
other  responsibilities,  selection  of  the  capacity  building  initiatives  and  literacy  programs  to  be 
financed  by  the  Fund.  SBP  shall  prepare  the  Fund  rules,  including  provisions  on  fund 
management,  accounting  and  auditing  procedures,  investment  policy,  grant  selection  criteria 
and  a  minimum  percentage  of  funds  available  each  year  for  literacy  programs  with  the 
concurrence of ADB.     
 
The  secretariat  of  the  Fund  will  be  located  at  SBP  headquarters.  In  order  to  promote 
7. 
transparency and greater accountability, the Fund will have a dedicated public website, hosted 
by  SBP,  which  will  list  application  criteria  for  accessing  grants  from  the  Fund  for  literacy  and 
capacity  building  programs,  and  provide  the  necessary  forms  and  instructions  for  application 
and the contact information for queries and the submission of applications. The Governing Body 
will  be  responsible  for publishing  on  a  quarterly  basis  on  the  SBP  public  website  the  listing  of 
recipients of funds and detailed information on the capacity building and training activities that 
are funded by the Fund. The Fund’s annual work plan will also be published by the Committee 
on  the  website  and  updated  quarterly  for  any  changes.  The  Fund  account  will  be  audited 
annually in accordance with internationally acceptable accounting norms and practices.
